S-X2
649. Dunlop Fannie Serena (Mrs. R.F.B.)
S-X2
649. Dunlop Fannie Serena (Mrs. R.F.B.)
Dunlop, Mrs. Fannie S. (Mrs. R.F.B.)
Holbein P.O., Sask.
To Sask. - August, 1902.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES
No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about having blank spaces. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

2 other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who has lived in exactly the same circumstances as another can be found. The questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, or don't worry about having blank spaces. If you have any information about pioneer life which you feel should be included, please fill in the blank spaces.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer business
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name (given) ____________________________
2. Your address ______________________________________
3. Date _______________________________________________
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) ____________________________
5. What was your father's name and occupation? ____________________________
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) ____________________________
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. ____________________________
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you do not know or you may say "I was in my teens," etc.) ____________________________
9. What were your reasons for coming? ____________________________
10. How did you learn about the West? ____________________________

The questionnaires were filled out by Dunlop Fannie Serena (Mrs. R.F.B.) in 1902.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name (given) ____________________________
2. Your address ______________________________________
3. Date _____________________________________________
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) ____________________________
5. What was your father's name and occupation? ____________________________
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) ____________________________
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates whenever possible. ____________________________
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you are under 18 years of age.) ____________________________
9. What were your reasons for coming here? ____________________________
10. How did you learn about the West? ____________________________

The following questions are for information only:

11. Did you have any relatives in the West? ____________________________
12. Did you have any friends in the West? ____________________________
13. Did you have any difficulties in coming to the West? ____________________________
14. Did you have any difficulties in settling in the West? ____________________________
15. Did you have any difficulties in getting work in the West? ____________________________
16. Did you have any difficulties in getting food in the West? ____________________________
17. Did you have any difficulties in getting shelter in the West? ____________________________
18. Did you have any difficulties in getting clothing in the West? ____________________________
19. Did you have any difficulties in getting transportation in the West? ____________________________
20. Did you have any difficulties in getting medical care in the West? ____________________________
12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)?
13. What means of transportation did you use?
14. What was the weather like during your trip?
15. How did you feel when you arrived at your destination?

Dear [Name],

I am writing to you from [Location]. We have been here for a few days now and everything has been going well so far. The weather has been quite pleasant and we have enjoyed exploring the area.

We had to stay in Regina for a few days because we needed to meet with officials and attend meetings with Indians. The journey has been quite long and we have encountered many challenges along the way. However, we are grateful for the opportunity to be here and we look forward to seeing more of Canada.

Please let us know how you are doing and if there is anything we can help you with. We hope to see you soon!

Best regards,

[Your Name]
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought it was a good idea.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)? We traveled with a party.

13. Did you have any children? Yes, we had two children.

14. What means of transportation did you use? We used a horse-drawn carriage.

15. How long did it take to reach the settlement? It took us about six months.

16. What difficulties did you face during your journey? We faced many difficulties, including sickness, lack of food, and harsh weather conditions.

17. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? We worked as farmers.

18. How did you earn a living after coming to Western Canada? We continued working as farmers.

19. How did you earn a living after coming to Western Canada? We continued working as farmers.
21. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came East tall when they came and where they settled, my aunt Emma and her husband came three years after I did with their children. They moved to Big River where such a place was available by the railroad.

22. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount? Indeed! We traveled myself and my brother Blumrager Butler (names misspelled) living in a tent on the Virginia border in 1851. We had no horses or mules and walked all night through the woods and fields. We had to push the load ourselves and carry our own supplies. It was a difficult journey but we arrived safely at our destination.

23. What was the most memorable moment in the early years? For business attending church, visiting friends, or other events?

24. Did you travel extensively? How often? By what means of travel?

25. Was family life not hard or too burdensome then?

We usually did not travel much or far because there were no trains or highways and we were forced to walk. When you wanted to go anywhere you had to walk through the woods and fields. It was a difficult journey but we arrived safely at our destination.
23. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came East tall when they came and where they settled, my grandpa came three years after I went to live in Pennsylvania. My grandpa came three years after I went to live in Pennsylvania.

24. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your mind? Yes, there was one experience that stands out in my mind. It was when we moved from Virginia to Pennsylvania. We traveled by horseback and walked through the woods. It was very difficult and we had to carry all our belongings on our backs. We also had to cross many streams and rivers. It was a long and tiring journey, but we finally arrived in Pennsylvania.

25. Did you travel about much in the early years? For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.? Yes, we did travel about much in the early years. We visited friends and attended church regularly.

26. How did you travel? By what means of travel? We usually did not travel much or far because there were no roads or bridges. We traveled on foot or by horseback.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

No one left that I know of.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return? Not away from here in any number but many people came in from the Wheat Bowl of the prairie. Many have gone in the last 10 years however.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

None other than father being chairman of the Wild Rose school for many years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

Nothing of any importance other than my brother Oliver buying his Ford car which was the second car to be in the district of Wild Rose. Mr. Leonard Painter bought the first one.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

The name of Wild Rose was given because of the acres and acres of Wild Roses which covered the land in spring. I think And was chosen by Mrs. J.W. Smith, now deceased, that was in 1906. Mrs. Smith was the first Post mistress in Wild Rose. The name of Holbein/my late Post mistress in Wild Rose. The name of Holbein was chosen by Mr. J.M. Miller who homesteaded here in 1907. Being an artist of no mean ability and a great admirer of the German painter Holbein, that was his choice and in 1909 or 1910 Holbein siding was named when the post office was first put in here with the late C. Banks as post master. Holbein has grown to be a thriving community and a rich farming district also the Village is growing fast. A wonderful change from those first days.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? If so, mention all they have for moving.

No one left church known of.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

From here in and around but many have left many have returned.

Many have gone in the last 10 years known.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices, or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

None other than teachers being chairman of the Wild Rose school for many years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "citizen" to have or do something in the district mention it here stating date wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile; combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

Nothing of any importance otherwise known.

My husband Oliver buying his Ford car which was the second car to be in the district of Wild Rose.

The second car bought the first one.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (school districts, Post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and location of person suggesting place-name; (2) criteria and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in names since then; (5) date and reason for change.

The name of Wild Rose was given because of the land in spring. School and was chosen by Mrs. J. W. Poveshell.

Post office in Wild Rose. The name of Holcomb was chosen by Mr. J. A. Miller who homesteaded here in 1907. He was an artist of no mean ability and a great admirer of old England. His Holcomb that was his choice and was in 1909 for 1910 Holcomb post office was named after the first officer was Frank Poveshell he served as a township supervisor over a rich farming district also his village is growing fast a wonderful change from those first days.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe)

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying? .......

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon? .......

(indicate your preference, if any) ..................

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

I have one son Milton age 27, Ladysmith B.C., Robert 37, New Westminster, Gerald 28, Creekside B.C., Nelson, 22, Drillic Ent., Gilbert 30, Drillic Ent., a daughter Emma 24, Wandsworth Sact. I have 6 grandchildren. My mother is still living in Kamloops B.C. Age 76. Father died 9 years ago.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The advent of the telephone. Shortened the distance between neighbors. Even if the roads were bad there was the friendliness of the phone. Then the building of highways. The coming of the motor car taking place of the horse and wagon or the ox teams used by pioneers.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

Mrs. Mary Canfield Holbein
Mrs. Arthur Cowles Holbein
Mrs. W. J. Smith Wild Rose.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:

I have filled this myself. Mrs. F. S. Dunlop Holbein. Saskatchewan.
Would you or the person who could then either:

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Assembly, Regina, Saskatchewan?

If so, please give the following information:

Name:
Address:
Phone number:
Occupation:
Age:
Sex:
Race:
Ethnic origin:
Religion:
Children:
Spouse:
Parents:
Siblings:
Other relatives:
Friends:
Neighbours:
Schools attended:
Employment history:
Marriage history:
Military service:
Other important events in your life:

Please give the names and addresses of other persons who could answer these questions.

I have filled this form myself.

Signature: [Signature]

Date: [Date]
If Slimtrim Fasteners are to be included, please specify.

Mississauga, Ontario L5T 1M8
Oxford
